spans.content: Weak radiative decays of antitriplet bottomed baryons in light-front quark model
Chao-Qiang Geng, Chia-Wei Liu, Zheng-Yi Wei
School of Fundamental Physics and Mathematical Sciences, Hangzhou Institute for Advanced Study, UCAS, Hangzhou 310024, China
We study the weak radiative decays of
the antitriplet bottomed (octet) baryons in the light-front quark model. We obtain that
, which agrees well with the current experimental value of
, which are consistent with the latest upper limits set by the LHCb Collaboration. In addition, we find that the
flavor symmetry breaking effects for the modes related to the
transition can be as large as
It is known that in the weak radiative decays associated with the
transition the photons are purely left handed in the standard model (SM) to

precision. Clearly, a signal of the right-handed photons in the experiment would be a smoking gun of new physics [1-9]. However, as the photon polarizations cannot be measured directly at the current experimental

facilities, such as LHCb, we have to analyze the cascade decays of hadrons to extract the polarization information [10-14]. In addition, since the two-body radiative decays are factorizable, the processes have a clean background for the theoretical computation.
Recently, the LHCb Collaboration has reported the following decay branching ratios [15,16]:
which are the same sizes as the charmless nonleptonic two-body decays. Remarkably, the LHCb Collaboration has also measured the lifetimes of the antitriplet bottomed baryons
with high precision [17,18] and carried out a full angular analysis for
[19]. These results in the baryon decays clearly provide great opportunities to test the SM. On the theoretical side, the radiative bottom decays of
been studied with many approaches, such as the heavy quark effective theory [20], perturbative QCD [21],

flavor symmetry [22], light-cone sum rule (LCSR) [23,24], Bethe-Salpeter equation (BSE) [25], quark model (QM) [26-29], and effective Lagrangian [30]. In this paper, we adopt the light-front quark model (LFQM), where the quark spins and the center-of-mass motions of hadrons can be treated in a consistent and fully relativistic manner, as the wave functions of the baryons are manifestly boost invariant.

The LFQM has been extensively studied in the mesonic processes [31-43] as well as the baryon semileptonic and nonleptonic ones [44-50]. However, in the LFQM, the transition form factors can only be calculated in the nontime-like region. To obtain the form factors in the timelike region, where the semileptonic and nonleptonic decays occur, certain
dependencies must be assumed, reducing the predicting power of the LFQM. In contrast, such a drawback does not exist in
, allowing the LFQM to be tested more rigorously.
As a complement, we also show the results from the

flavor symmetry similar to those in Ref. [22], which works well in the bottomed meson [51-59] and baryon decays [60-65] as well as the charmed meson [66-70] and baryon decays [65,71-79], and compare them with our evaluations from the LFQM.

This paper is organized as follows. In Sec. II, we present the formalisms for the decay widths and the tensor form factors. The numerical results and discussions are given in Sec. III. We conclude in Sec. IV.
We consider the weak radiative decays of antitriplet bottomed baryons induced by the quark transitions of

-exchange diagrams since they are suppressed by the CKM (Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa) elements. The effective Hamiltonians from the transitions are given by [80]

\begin{array}{l} \mathcal {H} _ {\mathrm {e f f}} (b \to f \gamma) \\ = - \frac {G _ {F}}{\sqrt {2}} \frac {e}{4 \pi^ {2}} V _ {t f} ^ {*} V _ {t b} C _ {\gamma} ^ {\text {e f f}} (\mu_ {b}) m _ {b} [ \bar {f} i \sigma^ {\mu k} (1 + \gamma^ {5}) b ] \epsilon_ {\mu}, \tag {2} \\ \end{array}
corresponds to the effective Wilson coefficient at the scale of
. The decay amplitudes are obtained by sandwiching
with the initial and final states,

\begin{array}{l} \mathcal {M} (\mathbf {B} _ {b} \rightarrow \mathbf {B} _ {n} \gamma) \\ = - \frac {G _ {F}}{\sqrt {2}} \frac {e}{4 \pi^ {2}} V _ {t f} ^ {*} V _ {t b} C _ {7 \gamma} ^ {\text {e f f}} (\mu_ {b}) m _ {b} \left\langle \mathbf {B} _ {n} \right| \bar {f} i \sigma^ {\mu k} (1 + \gamma^ {5}) b | \mathbf {B} _ {b} \rangle \epsilon_ {\mu}. \tag {3} \\ \end{array}
The matrix elements above can be parametrized in terms of the tensor form factors, given by

\begin{array}{l} \left\langle \mathbf {B} _ {n} | \bar {f} i \sigma^ {\mu k} b | \mathbf {B} _ {b} \right\rangle = \bar {u} _ {\mathbf {B} _ {n}} \left[ f _ {1} ^ {T V} \left(k ^ {2}\right) \left(\gamma^ {\mu} k ^ {2} - k ^ {\mu} k ^ {\prime}\right) / M _ {\mathbf {B} _ {b}} \right. \\ - f _ {2} ^ {T V} (k ^ {2}) i \sigma^ {\mu k} ] u _ {\mathbf {B} _ {h}}, \\ \end{array}

\begin{array}{l} \langle \mathbf {B} _ {n} | \bar {f} i \sigma^ {\mu k} \gamma^ {5} b | \mathbf {B} _ {b} \rangle = \bar {u} _ {\mathbf {B} _ {n}} \left[ f _ {1} ^ {T A} (k ^ {2}) (\gamma^ {\mu} k ^ {2} - k ^ {\mu} k) / M _ {\mathbf {B} _ {b}} \right. \\ - f _ {2} ^ {T A} \left(k ^ {2}\right) i \sigma^ {\mu k} ] \gamma^ {5} u _ {\mathbf {B} _ {b}}, \tag {4} \\ \end{array}
stands for the Dirac spinor of
the momentum transfer between the initial and final states. In our case of the radiative decays,
. We neglect the contributions associated with the form factors of
unless particularly noted in the rest of this paper. Consequently, the decay rates are given as

\begin{array}{l} \Gamma (\mathbf {B} _ {b} \rightarrow \mathbf {B} _ {n} \gamma) = \frac {\alpha_ {e m}}{6 4 \pi^ {4}} G _ {F} ^ {2} m _ {b} ^ {2} M _ {\mathbf {B} _ {b}} ^ {3} | V _ {t f} ^ {*} V _ {t b} | ^ {2} (C _ {7 \gamma} ^ {\mathrm {e f f}}) ^ {2} \\ \times \left(1 - \frac {M _ {\mathbf {B} _ {n}} ^ {2}}{M _ {\mathbf {B} _ {b}} ^ {2}}\right) ^ {3} \left(| f _ {2} ^ {T V} | ^ {2} + | f _ {2} ^ {T A} | ^ {2}\right). \tag {5} \\ \end{array}
the fine-structure constant of the electromagnetic interaction.
Unfortunately, to calculate the form factors of

, the baryon wave functions are required, which cannot be reliably obtained from the first principle due to the nonperturbative effect. In this work, we use the approach in the LFQM for the baryon wave functions, in which a baryon state with momentum

\begin{array}{l} \left| B, P, S, S _ {z} \right\rangle = \sum_ {\lambda_ {1}, \lambda_ {2}, \lambda_ {3}} \int \left\{d ^ {3} \tilde {p} _ {1} \right\} \left\{d ^ {3} \tilde {p} _ {2} \right\} \left\{d ^ {3} \tilde {p} _ {3} \right\} 2 (2 \pi) ^ {3} \\ \times \frac {1}{\sqrt {P ^ {+}}} \delta^ {3} (\tilde {P} - \tilde {p} _ {1} - \tilde {p} _ {2} - \tilde {p} _ {3}) \\ \times \Psi^ {S S _ {z}} \left(\tilde {p} _ {1}, \tilde {p} _ {2}, \tilde {p} _ {3}, \lambda_ {1}, \lambda_ {2}, \lambda_ {3}\right) \\ \times C ^ {\alpha \beta \gamma} F _ {a b c} \left| q _ {\alpha} ^ {a} \left(\tilde {p} _ {1}, \lambda_ {1}\right) q _ {\beta} ^ {b} \left(\tilde {p} _ {2}, \lambda_ {2}\right) q _ {\gamma} ^ {c} \left(\tilde {p} _ {3}, \lambda_ {3}\right) \right\rangle , \tag {6} \\ \end{array}
represents the vertex function between the baryon and quarks, and
corresponds to the color (flavor) factor with
the light-front three-momenta of the ith constituent quark, defined by
p _ {i} = \left(p _ {i} ^ {-}, p _ {i} ^ {+}, p _ {i} ^ {1}, p _ {i} ^ {2}\right) = \left(p _ {i} ^ {-}, \tilde {p} _ {i}\right) = \left(p _ {i} ^ {-}, p _ {i} ^ {+}, p _ {i \perp}\right), \tag {7}
. Here, the integration measure and delta function are given as

\langle \mathbf {B}, P ^ {\prime}, S ^ {\prime}, S _ {z} ^ {\prime} | \mathbf {B}, P, S, S _ {z} \rangle = 2 (2 \pi) ^ {3} P ^ {+} \delta^ {3} (\tilde {P} ^ {\prime} - \tilde {P}) \delta_ {S _ {z} ^ {\prime} S _ {z}}. \tag {9}
The vertex function can be further decomposed as [31,32,85]
is the momentum distribution function, and
stands for the helicity wave function given as

\Xi^ {S S _ {z}} \left(\lambda_ {1}, \lambda_ {2}, \lambda_ {3}\right) = \sum_ {s _ {1}, s _ {2}, s _ {3}} \prod_ {i = 1} ^ {3} \left\langle \lambda_ {i} \right| R _ {i} ^ {\dagger} | s _ {i} \rangle \left\langle \frac {1}{2} s _ {1}, \frac {1}{2} s _ {2}, \frac {1}{2} s _ {3} \right| S S _ {z} \Bigg \rangle , \tag {11}
is the Melosh matrix, which brings the
th quark from its spin state to a helicity state, and
is the Clebsch-Gordan coefficient, embodied in the spin wave function.

depend on the parametrization scheme of the internal motions of the constituent quarks. In our calculation, we choose the diquark scheme with the first two quarks being coupled to each other, while the other coupling schemes can be easily done by the permutations [49]. The kinematic variables are given as
describe the internal motion within the diquark system, with
the relative motion between the diquark and the third quark [86]. The invariant masses are then given as
In this work, we adopt the Gaussian-type momentum wave function for the ground state baryon [31,49,50]. In this particular set of kinematic variables, we have that

\begin{array}{l} \phi_ {3} \equiv \Phi (\xi_ {3}, q _ {3 \perp}, \eta_ {3}, Q _ {3 \perp}) \\ = \mathcal {N} \sqrt {\frac {\partial q _ {3 z}}{\partial \xi_ {3}} \frac {\partial Q _ {3 z}}{\partial \eta_ {3}}} \exp \left(- \frac {\vec {Q} _ {3} ^ {2}}{2 \beta_ {Q} ^ {2}} - \frac {\vec {q} _ {3} {} ^ {2}}{2 \beta_ {q q ^ {\prime}} ^ {2}}\right), \tag {14} \\ \end{array}

are the confinement energy scales within the diquark system and between the diquark and third quark, respectively. Note that we take the shape parameters as the internal kinematic freedoms to describe the diquark systems instead of the diquark masses. If the integration variables
where the wave functions are clearly Gaussian. On the other hand, the angular dependencies are embodied in
R _ {1} = R _ {M} \left(\eta_ {3}, Q _ {3 \perp}, M _ {3}, M\right) R _ {M} \left(\xi_ {3}, q _ {3 \perp}, m _ {1}, M _ {3}\right),
R _ {2} = R _ {M} \left(\eta_ {3}, Q _ {3 \perp}, M _ {3}, M\right) R _ {M} \left(1 - \xi_ {3}, - q _ {3 \perp}, m _ {2}, M _ {3}\right),
R _ {M} (\xi , q _ {\perp}, m, M) = \frac {m + \xi M - i \vec {\sigma} \cdot (\vec {n} \times \vec {q})}{\sqrt {(m + \xi M) ^ {2} + q _ {\perp} ^ {2}}}, \tag {18}
. We emphasize that the explicit forms of
As the baryon wave functions are given, we are now ready to calculate the form factors. To illustrate the calculation, we take
as an example, while the others can be obtained with slight modifications. The relevant ones in Eq. (5) can be extracted through the following equalities:
f _ {2} ^ {T V} = \frac {1}{4 P ^ {+}} \langle \Lambda , P ^ {\prime}, \uparrow | \bar {f} i \sigma^ {R +} b | \Lambda_ {b}, P, \downarrow \rangle ,
f _ {2} ^ {T A} = - \frac {1}{4 P ^ {+}} \langle \Lambda , P ^ {\prime}, \uparrow | \bar {f} i \sigma^ {R +} \gamma_ {5} b | \Lambda_ {b}, P, \downarrow \rangle , \tag {19}
, and the Dirac spinors in the light-front formalism can be found in the Appendix A. We choose

to perform the calculation. In the LFQMs, this particular frame is often used to avoid the zero-mode graphs [87-91]. It has been shown that their contributions to the vector form factors vanish at the limit of
[31,32]. In this work, we would take it as a working assumption for the tensor ones and test it with the experimental data.

\begin{array}{l} \left| \Lambda_ {b} \right\rangle = \frac {1}{\sqrt {6}} \left[ \phi_ {3} \chi^ {\rho 3} \left(\left| u d b \right\rangle - \left| d u b \right\rangle\right) + \phi_ {2} \chi^ {\rho 2} \left(\left| u b d \right\rangle - \left| d b u \right\rangle\right) \right. \\ + \phi_ {1} \chi^ {\rho 1} (| b u d \rangle - | b d u \rangle) ], \\ \end{array}

\begin{array}{l} \left| \Lambda \right\rangle = \frac {1}{\sqrt {6}} \left[ \phi_ {3} \chi^ {\rho 3} \left(\left| u d s \right\rangle - \left| d u s \right\rangle\right) + \phi_ {2} \chi^ {\rho 2} \left(\left| u s d \right\rangle - \left| d s u \right\rangle\right) \right. \\ + \phi_ {1} \chi^ {\rho 1} (| s u d \rangle - | s d u \rangle) ], \tag {20} \\ \end{array}
while the others can be found in Appendix B. In our study, since diquark clusters are viewed as effective particles, they are chosen in a way to acquire definite angular momenta. For

pairs to form diquark clusters instead of the others. This way of constructing the baryon wave functions would break the
flavor symmetry by hand, as it does not allow a diquark cluster with a light quark and a strange quark inside
. Such breaking effects are embedded in the expressions of the baryon octet, as the
baryons are taken to preserve the isospin symmetry instead of the
There are six terms which contribute to the transition, read as
WEAK RADIATIVE DECAYS OF ANTITRIPLET BOTTOMED ...
| u d b \rangle \to | u d s \rangle , \quad | d b u \rangle \to | d s u \rangle , \quad | b u d \rangle \to | s u d \rangle ,
| d u b \rangle \rightarrow | d u s \rangle , \quad | u b d \rangle \rightarrow | u s d \rangle , \quad | b d u \rangle \rightarrow | s d u \rangle . \tag {21}
The first one in Eq. (21) contributes to the form factors as

\begin{array}{l} \left(f _ {2} ^ {T V}\right) _ {u d b \rightarrow u d s} = \frac {1}{4 P ^ {+}} \int \mathrm {d} \xi_ {3} \mathrm {d} \eta_ {3} \mathrm {d} ^ {2} q _ {3 \perp} \mathrm {d} ^ {2} Q _ {3 \perp} \phi_ {3} ^ {\prime} \phi_ {3} F _ {u d s} F _ {u d b} \\ \times \sum_ {\lambda_ {i} ^ {\prime}, \lambda_ {i}} \Xi^ {\frac {1}{2}, + \frac {1}{2}} \left(\lambda_ {i} ^ {\prime}\right) ^ {\dagger} \delta_ {\lambda_ {1} ^ {\prime} \lambda_ {1}} \delta_ {\lambda_ {2} ^ {\prime} \lambda_ {2}} \left(O _ {3} ^ {T V}\right) _ {\lambda_ {3} ^ {\prime} \lambda_ {3}} \Xi^ {\frac {1}{2}, - \frac {1}{2}} (\lambda_ {i}), \tag {22} \\ \end{array}

\begin{array}{l} \left(O _ {3} ^ {T V}\right) _ {\lambda_ {3} ^ {\prime} \lambda_ {3}} = \frac {1}{1 - \eta} \bar {u} \left(\vec {p} _ {3} ^ {\prime} \lambda_ {3} ^ {\prime}\right) i \sigma^ {R +} u \left(\vec {p} _ {3} \lambda_ {3}\right) = - 4 P ^ {+} \left(\sigma^ {R}\right) _ {\lambda_ {3} ^ {\prime} \lambda_ {3}}, \\ \left(O _ {3} ^ {T A}\right) _ {\lambda_ {3} ^ {\prime} \lambda_ {3}} = \frac {1}{1 - \eta} \bar {u} \left(\vec {p} _ {3} ^ {\prime} \lambda_ {3} ^ {\prime}\right) i \sigma^ {R +} \gamma_ {5} u \left(\vec {p} _ {3} \lambda_ {3}\right) = 4 P ^ {+} \left(\sigma^ {R}\right) _ {\lambda_ {3} ^ {\prime} \lambda_ {3}}, \tag {23} \\ \end{array}
transition at the quark level, note that we have normalized
On the other hand, the helicity wave functions for the initial and final baryons are

\begin{array}{l} \left(f _ {2} ^ {T V}\right) _ {u d b \rightarrow u d s} = - \frac {1}{6} \int \mathrm {d} \xi_ {3} \mathrm {d} \eta_ {3} \mathrm {d} ^ {2} q _ {3 \perp} \mathrm {d} ^ {2} Q _ {3 \perp} \phi_ {3} ^ {\prime} \phi_ {3} \\ \times \sum_ {\chi_ {\uparrow} ^ {\rho 3} \chi_ {\downarrow} ^ {\rho 3}} \prod_ {i = 1, 2} \left\langle s _ {i} ^ {\prime} \right| R _ {i} ^ {\prime} \cdot R _ {i} ^ {\dagger} | s _ {i} \rangle \left\langle s _ {3} ^ {\prime} \right| R _ {3} ^ {\prime} \cdot \sigma^ {R} \cdot R _ {3} ^ {\dagger} | s _ {3} \rangle . \tag {25} \\ \end{array}

\begin{array}{l} \left(f _ {2} ^ {T A}\right) _ {u d b \rightarrow u d s} = - \frac {1}{6} \int \mathrm {d} \xi_ {3} \mathrm {d} \eta_ {3} \mathrm {d} ^ {2} q _ {3 \perp} \mathrm {d} ^ {2} Q _ {3 \perp} \phi_ {3} ^ {\prime} \phi_ {3} \\ \times \sum_ {\chi_ {\uparrow} ^ {\rho 3} \chi_ {\downarrow} ^ {\rho 3}} \prod_ {i = 1, 2} \left\langle s _ {i} ^ {\prime} \right| R _ {i} ^ {\prime} \cdot R _ {i} ^ {\dagger} | s _ {i} \rangle \left\langle s _ {3} ^ {\prime} \right| R _ {3} ^ {\prime} \cdot \sigma^ {R} \cdot R _ {3} ^ {\dagger} | s _ {3} \rangle . \tag {26} \\ \end{array}
By the permutation symmetry of the Fermi statistics, it is straightforward to see that the six transitions give exactly the same contributions to the form factors. As a result, the
transition form factors between the baryons can be obtained by multiplying Eqs. (25) and (26) by 6, given by

\begin{array}{l} \left(f _ {2} ^ {T V}\right) _ {\Lambda_ {b} \rightarrow \Lambda} = \left(f _ {2} ^ {T A}\right) _ {\Lambda_ {b} \rightarrow \Lambda} \\ = - \int \mathrm {d} \xi_ {3} \mathrm {d} \eta_ {3} \mathrm {d} ^ {2} q _ {3 \perp} \mathrm {d} ^ {2} Q _ {3 \perp} \phi_ {3} ^ {\prime} \phi_ {3} \\ \times \sum_ {\chi_ {\uparrow} ^ {\rho_ {3}} \chi_ {\downarrow} ^ {\rho_ {3}}} \prod_ {i = 1, 2} \left\langle s _ {i} ^ {\prime} \right| R _ {i} ^ {\prime} \cdot R _ {i} ^ {\dagger} | s _ {i} \rangle \left\langle s _ {3} ^ {\prime} \right| R _ {3} ^ {\prime} \cdot \sigma^ {R} \cdot R _ {3} ^ {\dagger} | s _ {3} \rangle , \tag {27} \\ \end{array}
It is worth mentioning that the equality
. This result is also consistent with that in Refs. [23,27].
The equivalence can be understood intuitively in terms of the valence quark framework, in which the spin direction of
is attributed to its strange quark solely. As a result, it is necessary for
to have the same helicity with the strange quark, which is left handed. A direct consequence is that
corresponds to the helicity amplitude with the subscript denoting the helicity of

, which can be determined by the experiments [92], and the definitions of the angles are given in Fig. 1, in which

P _ {L} \equiv \frac {\left| H _ {+} ^ {2} \right| - \left| H _ {-} ^ {2} \right|}{\left| H _ {+} ^ {2} \right| + \left| H _ {-} ^ {2} \right|} = - 1 + \mathcal {O} \left(m _ {s (d)} ^ {2} / m _ {b} ^ {2}\right), \tag {31}
where the second equality comes from Eq. (29). It is interesting to point out that the distribution is independent of
due to the angular momentum conservation. Note that in contrast to
a pseudoscalar meson, the up-down asymmetry parameter
has an opposite sign in respect to
. It is attributed to that the photon is spin-1 and transversely polarized.

APPENDIX A: DIRAC SPINOR IN LIGHT-FRONT FORMALISM
We adopt the notation given in Ref. [32] for the light-front formalism. The Dirac spinors turn out to be

u (p, \lambda) = \frac {1}{\sqrt {p ^ {+}}} (p ^ {+} + \beta + \boldsymbol {\alpha} _ {\perp} \mathbf {p} _ {\perp}) \times \left\{ \begin{array}{l l} \chi (\uparrow) & \text {f o r} \lambda = + 1 \\ \chi (\downarrow) & \text {f o r} \lambda = - 1 \end{array} , \right.

v (p, \lambda) = \frac {1}{\sqrt {p ^ {+}}} \left(p ^ {+} - \beta m + \boldsymbol {\alpha} _ {\perp} \mathbf {p} _ {\perp}\right) \times \left\{ \begin{array}{l l} \chi (\downarrow) & \text {f o r} \lambda = + 1 \\ \chi (\uparrow) & \text {f o r} \lambda = - 1 \end{array} , \right. \tag {A1}
being the Dirac gamma matrices, while the two
u (p, +) = \frac {1}{\sqrt {2 p ^ {+}}} \left( \begin{array}{c} p ^ {+} + m \\ p ^ {1} + i p ^ {2} \\ p ^ {+} - m \\ p ^ {1} + i p ^ {2} \end{array} \right) \quad \text {a n d}
u (p, -) = \frac {1}{\sqrt {2 p ^ {+}}} \left( \begin{array}{c} - p ^ {1} + i p ^ {2} \\ p ^ {+} + m \\ p ^ {1} - i p ^ {2} \\ - p ^ {+} + m \end{array} \right). \tag {A3}
Accordingly, the relations in Eq. (19) and (23) can be verified directly.

\begin{array}{l} | \Xi_ {b} ^ {-} \rangle = \frac {1}{\sqrt {6}} [ \phi_ {3} \chi^ {\rho 3} (| d s b \rangle - | s d b \rangle) + \phi_ {2} \chi^ {\rho 2} (| d b s \rangle - | s b d \rangle) + \phi_ {1} \chi^ {\rho 1} (| b d s \rangle - | b s d \rangle) ], \\ | \Xi_ {b} ^ {0} \rangle = \frac {1}{\sqrt {6}} \left[ \phi_ {3} \chi^ {\rho 3} (| u s b \rangle - | s u b \rangle) + \phi_ {2} \chi^ {\rho 2} (| u b s \rangle - | s b u \rangle) + \phi_ {1} \chi^ {\rho 1} (| b u s \rangle - | b s u \rangle) \right], \\ \left| \Lambda_ {b} ^ {0} \right\rangle = \frac {1}{\sqrt {6}} \left[ \phi_ {3} \chi^ {\rho 3} \left(\left| u d b \right\rangle - \left| d u b \right\rangle\right) + \phi_ {2} \chi^ {\rho 2} \left(\left| u b d \right\rangle - \left| d b u \right\rangle\right) + \phi_ {1} \chi^ {\rho 1} \left(\left| b u d \right\rangle - \left| b d u \right\rangle\right) \right], (B1) \\ | p \rangle = \frac {1}{\sqrt {3}} \phi \left[ \chi^ {\lambda 3} | u u d \rangle + \chi^ {\lambda 2} | u d u \rangle + \chi^ {\lambda 1} | d u u \rangle \right], \\ | n \rangle = \frac {1}{\sqrt {3}} \phi \left[ \chi^ {\lambda 3} | d d u \rangle + \chi^ {\lambda 2} | d u d \rangle + \chi^ {\lambda 1} | u d d \rangle \right], \\ \left| \Xi^ {0} \right\rangle = \frac {1}{\sqrt {3}} \left[ \phi_ {3} \chi^ {\lambda 3} | s s u \rangle + \phi_ {2} \chi^ {\lambda 2} | s u s \rangle + \phi_ {1} \chi^ {\lambda 1} | u s s \rangle \right], \\ \left| \Xi^ {-} \right\rangle = \frac {1}{\sqrt {3}} \left[ \phi_ {3} \chi^ {\lambda 3} | s s d \rangle + \phi_ {2} \chi^ {\lambda 2} | s d s \rangle + \phi_ {1} \chi^ {\lambda 1} | d s s \rangle \right], \\ \left| \Sigma^ {+} \right\rangle = \frac {1}{\sqrt {3}} \left[ \phi_ {3} \chi^ {\lambda 3} | u u s \rangle + \phi_ {2} \chi^ {\lambda 2} | u s u \rangle + \phi_ {1} \chi^ {\lambda 1} | s u u \rangle \right], \\ \left| \Sigma^ {-} \right\rangle = \frac {1}{\sqrt {3}} \left[ \phi_ {3} \chi^ {\lambda 3} | d d s \rangle + \phi_ {2} \chi^ {\lambda 2} | d s d \rangle + \phi_ {1} \chi^ {\lambda 1} | s d d \rangle \right], (B2) \\ \end{array}

\left| \Sigma^ {0} \right\rangle = \frac {1}{\sqrt {6}} \left[ \phi_ {3} \chi^ {\lambda 3} \left(\left| u d s \right\rangle + \left| d u s \right\rangle\right) + \phi_ {2} \chi^ {\lambda 2} \left(\left| u s d \right\rangle + \left| d s u \right\rangle\right) + \phi_ {1} \chi^ {\lambda 1} \left(\left| s u d \right\rangle + \left| s d u \right\rangle\right) \right],

\left| \Lambda \right\rangle = \frac {1}{\sqrt {6}} \left[ \phi_ {3} \chi^ {\rho 3} \left(\left| u d s \right\rangle - \left| d u s \right\rangle\right) + \phi_ {2} \chi^ {\rho 2} \left(\left| u s d \right\rangle - \left| d s u \right\rangle\right) + \phi_ {1} \chi^ {\rho 1} \left(\left| s u d \right\rangle - \left| s d u \right\rangle\right) \right]. \tag {B3}
